title: Newly Renovated House in Bristol Lists for £1.575 Million
text:
In 2016, interior designer Andrew Henry bought a 2,200-square-foot rotting home that was built in 1970.



“Oh my God,” he said. “It wasn’t a particularly attractive house.”



Mr. Henry, 50, renovated the two-story, L-shaped house into a contemporary three-story house with an open floor plan and high ceilings. Completed last year, the home near Bristol, England, where Mr. Henry now lives, listed last month for £1.575 million (US$1.965 million). Richard Brooks from Savills has the listing.



“It was very dated, very tired [and] very rundown,” Mr. Henry said.



Mr. Henry said he was ultimately drawn to the home’s location in Sneyd Park, three miles northwest of Bristol city center. “It presented a great opportunity to buy a house in that location at a price that I probably couldn’t afford if it had been all modernized,” Mr. Henry said.



Designated as Quaker land, Sneyd Park is an ideal family neighborhood free of bars or pubs, Mr. Brooks said. The house is also situated adjacent to the Durdham Down nature reserve.



More: Whisper Listings Can Mean Deals to Buyers, but Most Benefits Go to the Seller

Mr. Henry said the 3,777-square-foot house is a bit big for him and his new partner, but is move-in ready for someone who wants or needs the space. “My house is crying out for a family to enjoy it,” Mr. Henry said.



The five-bedroom, five-bathroom home features three en-suite bedrooms and bathrooms, including the master bedroom, which spans the entirety of the third floor. The master bedroom also features a Juliet balcony that looks over an artificial grass terrace supported by fiberglass flooring offering elevated views of the gardens.



The rest of the house boasts high vaulted ceilings, floor-to-ceiling windows and underfloor heating.



“The kitchen/breakfast/family space is very much designed for family living,” Mr. Henry said.

There is also a home gym, a raised sundeck with a concealed hot tub and a garage.



Mr. Henry and his partner are planning to move to the Cotswolds, he said.
